notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 14, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course in Modern Irish Language is designed for learners with no prior knowledge of the language. The course is intended to introduce students to and provide practice in the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to the Irish Language

courses.name: SMC One: The McLuhan Seminar in Creativity and Technology

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Location of lecture: Coach House in McLuhan Centre for Culture and Technology, 39 Queen's Park East, Room Change: September 20, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar is an interdisciplinary exploration of the relationship between creativity and technology. Inspired by the innovative thinking of Marshall McLuhan, it explores how the humanities relate to other fields of thought and research in addressing the individual, social and cultural experiences and effects of technological innovation. This course includes a mandatory travel component opportunity to Silicon Valley, California, the costs of which, including transportation, room and board, are covered by the University of St. Michael's College.
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The McLuhan Seminar in Creativity and Technology
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC165H1, SMC188H1, SMC189H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

courses.name: SMC One: The Boyle Seminar in Scripts and Stories

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 22, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar introduces students to university-level studies through an interdisciplinary exploration of Celtic influences in the mediaeval world, with a particular focus on early books and historical artifacts as physical objects and bearers of meaning. Students will learn how to read and analyse these books and artifacts to decode their meanings, and, in support of that, take introductory language instruction in Latin or Irish. Subjects discussed will include intercultural encounter and dialogue, research methods with historical sources, and the relationship between the written word and lived experience, then and now. There is a co-curricular travel opportunity to Dublin, Ireland associated with this course which is strongly recommended. The costs of this travel opportunity are covered by the University of St. Michael's College.
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The Boyle Seminar in Scripts and Stories
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC155H1, SMC188H1, SMC189H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College). Students should register in the tutorial of their choice: TUT0101 (Professor Coilfeir) for Irish language; TUT0201 (Professor More) for Latin.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to medieval ecclesiastical Latin based principally on the Vulgate Bible, the major texts of Christian worship, and a selection of texts from later medieval Latin.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval Christian Latin for Beginners

courses.name: SMC One: The Gilson Seminar in Faith and Ideas

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: August 28, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar is an interdisciplinary exploration of leading scholarly, intellectual and public questions related to ecology, science, literature, and public life. From a variety of perspectives, the seminar considers how religion, and how different kinds of religious experience, figure in the broader context of human affairs. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The Gilson Seminar in Faith and Ideas
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC155H1, SMC165H1, SMC188Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

courses.name: SMC One: The Gilson Seminar in Faith and Rome

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Added: November 15, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an intensive international learning experience in Rome, Italy. It offers contemporary and historical models of integrating faith with reason, and religious practice with intellectual, creative, and public engagement, specifically the roles that the Catholic Church and Vatican play in Rome, in ecology, science, literature, and public life. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. This course includes a mandatory travel component to Rome, Italy, the costs of which, including transportation, room and board, are covered by the University of St. Michael's College.
cmCourseInfo.title: SMC One: The Gilson Seminar in Faith and Rome
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, Trinity One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One, SMC155H1, SMC165H1, SMC188Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to creative works from throughout the global Christian tradition. The course explores the complex relationships that exist between religious and aesthetic imperatives, between theological and material sources, between beauty and suffering, and between artists and their patrons and audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and the Arts

courses.name: Christianity and Society Through the Ages

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the historical engagement of various Christian traditions with the prevailing political, social, and ethnic cultures in the western world and beyond. Students will also examine the development of Christianity as it confronts changes in the symbolic and intellectual universes from antiquity to post-modernity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Society Through the Ages

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 14, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the thought and culture of early mediaeval Europe.  Students are introduced to important monuments of early mediaeval History, Thought, Literature, and Art.  They follow some of the common threads that run through these disciplines and explore chief expressions of early mediaeval life and thought.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Early Mediaeval Tradition

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of pedagogy and child development theory, with a particular focus on the way Christians have employed these educational techniques historically. Attention will be given to the diversity of institutions and approaches to curriculum development across Christian history.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Education

courses.name: Mass Media in Culture and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to acquaint students with the essential notions of media studies, and to promote a conscious utilization of contemporary media. Starting with the preliminary definitions of media, mass, and communications, the student is invited to consider critically the cultural constructs created by modern media, from print to photography, filming, TV, computer and Internet.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mass Media in Culture and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: This course studies a selection of mediaeval Latin prose and poetry. Emphasis is on the linguistic differences between mediaeval Latin and its classical antecedent, especially in regard to vocabulary, grammar and orthography. A review of Latin grammar is part of the course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Latin I (formerly LAT322H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the Arthurian legends from the earliest Latin histories through selected Welsh, French and German Romances to the English-language classic, Morte d’Arthur of Malory. Emphasis will be on reading the primary sources (in translation).
cmCourseInfo.title: King Arthur
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

courses.name: Elements of Material Bibliography and Print Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An historical introduction to the evolution of printing processes since Gutenberg. Attention is given to topics such as the mechanization of printing, the industrialization of the book chain since the nineteenth century, typography and publishing. Visits to rare book collections are an integral part of the course. Note: this course is not intended as a guide to self-publishing nor as a workshop on book making.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elements of Material Bibliography and Print Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of reading in western culture, from ancient Greece to the twenty-first century. Attention is given to topics such as the causes and effects of different modes of reading (silent or vocalized, intensive or extensive, educational or escapist), book clubs, censorship, and the ways in which readers have influenced cultural production.
cmCourseInfo.title: Readers and Readerships

courses.name: Models of Relating Christianity and Science

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines different models of relating Christianity and Science. Beginning with the biblical view on the natural world and moving to the present, the lectures develop a wide range of approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Models of Relating Christianity and Science

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the cultural study of modern Celtic nations from 1600 to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Celtic Cultures II: Modern

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day Changed: July 30, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to Scottish Gaelic language and culture. Students will master fundamentals of reading, writing, and the basics of grammar and will begin to speak Gaelic. Proverbs, poetry, songs and folktales introduce students to the language, literature and folklore of Gaelic Scotland and immigrant North America. No prior knowledge of the language is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: An Introduction to Scottish Gaelic

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day and Time Change: August 2, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course builds on SMC141Y1 Introduction to the Irish Language. It will provide further expansion of the four language skills: listening, speaking, reading and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Irish Language I

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a continuation of SMC251H1 Intermediate Irish Language I. It will provide further expansion of language skills. We will examine literary texts, both prose and poetry.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Irish Language II

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to provide for individual half-courses not already covered in the listed range of the Book and Media Studies Program offerings.  Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
What is an archive? What is a primary source? This course takes a hands-on approach to introduce students to different types of printed and manuscript materials for primary source research. Through a combination of lectures, tours, and guest speakers, students will discover, critique, and apply library and archival theories to current practices using items from the University of St. Michael's College Archives and the John M. Kelly Library Special Collections.

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Bibliographical and Textual Studies: Print Culture in Practice

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: October 9, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Designed to provide for individual half-courses not already covered in the listed range of the Book and Media Studies Program offerings.  Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course follows from the SMC228H1 course as a more in-depth study of book history and print culture, examining the history of bibliographic scholarship and printing technology, the rise of the publishing industry and popular literary genres, and the material aspects of book production. Students will examine the textual transfer of a chosen text from manuscript or edition to published text, and engage with the editorial process and physical bibliographic scholarship manifested in the material stages of composition and publication.

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 13, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality) completed in Fall 2016; SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality and Transmedia) completed in Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The election of President Donald Trump has transformed the relationship between the presidency and the press. But what has been the larger impact on American democracy? We will look for answers by examining a broad range of political journalism - legacy print publications, network and cable news, and newer forms of digital and social media.

courses.name: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college website for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality) completed in Fall 2016; SMC301H1 (Special Topics in Book and Media Studies II: Seriality and Transmedia) completed in Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
One of the most significant developments in popular media since the late 1970s is the rise and proliferation of media franchises, which spread their commercial interests and fictional worlds across many multiple media. Reflective of the broader logics of media industry conglomeration and convergence, in media franchises movies, television series, novels and comics, games of all kinds, toys and merchandise, paratexts like promotional materials, etc. are linked together in order to maximize profits. These dense networks of commercial products serve as a platform for new forms of serial narrative and world-building such as "transmedia storytelling," and also generate vibrant, diverse fan cultures that extend far beyond the official franchise and its canonical texts. Drawing on a wide range of scholarly and critical work, this course examines the modern media franchise from historical, industrial, formal/aesthetic, and sociocultural perspectives. Media franchises to be examined include Marvel, Star Wars, DC, Harry Potter, The Matrix, and more. (This course was previously offered as SMC301 Seriality and Transmedia.)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 20, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of Canon Law; the process by which it came into being, and its impact on contemporary culture. Premises and techniques of ecclesial law-making are compared to those of other systems of legislation. Specific sections of the Code of Canon Law are examined.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity, Law and Society

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of both overt and covert representations of Christian ideas in contemporary popular media. We examine the ways in which Christian themes have been appropriated and subverted in mass media, while also examining the innovative ways these themes, such as redemption, sacrifice, vocation, and hope, are presented anew.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Popular Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of both overt and covert representations of Christian ideas in contemporary popular media. We examine the ways in which Christian themes have been appropriated and subverted in mass media, while also examining the innovative ways these themes, such as redemption, sacrifice, vocation, and hope, are presented anew.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity and Popular Culture

courses.name: The Catechism of the Catholic Church

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 22, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to the Catechism of the Catholic Church (1994) and its antecedents. After an historical survey of religious instruction in the Church, the students will engage in a close reading of selected sections of the Catechism of the Catholic Church.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Catechism of the Catholic Church

cmCourseInfo.description: The Catholic Church claims to be the continuation of the event of Christ in history, the guarantor of the authenticity of each person's encounter with Christ, and the means by which His memory may be cultivated. The course examines the reasons for these claims and the forms they have taken.
cmCourseInfo.title: Why the Church

cmCourseInfo.description: Facebook, MySpace, Google+.  Social technology tools are entwined in modern life.  But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, and how we understand ourselves, both as global citizens and as humans?  Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Technology and Networks
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment priority for students enrolled in a Book and Media Studies program

cmCourseInfo.description: Facebook, MySpace, Google+.  Social technology tools are entwined in modern life.  But what consequences do they have for how we think, how we feel, how we socialize, and how we understand ourselves, both as global citizens and as humans?  Students in this course will explore, examine, and debate these questions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Technology and Networks
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment priority for students enrolled in a Book and Media Studies program

cmCourseInfo.description: Applying the thought of key media theorists (Innis, McLuhan, Habermas, Fiske, etc.) to the historical symbiosis between music and media, students in this course explore communications from oral storytelling to YouTube, as well as examine the relationship between music and other arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Books, Media, and Music

cmCourseInfo.description: Provides students with a theoretical foundation that enables them to identify and analyze ethical issues in mainstream and non-mainstream media.  Traditional principles of journalistic truth-seeking, objectivity, and minimizing harm are revisited in the light of global, interactive media, produced by both citizens and professionals.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Ethics

cmCourseInfo.description: Through the close reading of fewer but longer texts than in SMC222H1, this course gives students a deepened acquaintance of the linguistic features of mediaeval Latin, as well as with its literature, and generic and stylistic conventions. A solid foundation in basic Latin morphology, syntax and vocabulary is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mediaeval Latin II (formerly LAT323H1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 26, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Faith in Christ is central to Christianity. This course offers an advanced introduction to classical debates about the person and work of Christ, the modern Quest of the Historical Jesus, and selected feminist, liberationist and indigenized perspectives on Christ from Asia, Africa and Latin America.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christ in Christian Tradition

courses.name: Special Topics in Celtic Studies I

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Day and Time Change: August 3, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Various topics are taken up each year, the content of which depends on the instructor. Students should check the college web site for details.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Celtic Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Speaking, writing and reading competence is emphasized. The course concentrates on the study of modern Irish literary texts, both poetry and prose and advanced translation into the Irish language.

cmCourseInfo.description: The history of the insular Celtic nation groups from the post-Roman period to the end of the first millennium, the course will trace settlement history and social organization, the making of Celtic nations, the process of Christianization, the impact of the Vikings, and the rise of paramount kings (offered every three years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Celtic History 450-1000

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 12, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description:
The archaeology of the Celtic peoples, with special reference to settlement patterns and material culture in Great Britain and Ireland.
(offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Celtic Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the relationship between folklore and national identity in Ireland, Scotland and Wales, with special emphasis on storytelling traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Celtic Folklore
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the most salient aspects of mediaeval manuscript culture. We will study, first, how the parchment for books was folded, pricked, ruled and bound, and second, what scripts were employed in the different codices. We will also examine the various types of books made in the Middle Ages and the challenges they pose to modern scholars.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Mediaeval Book
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: LAT100Y1/LAT102H1; SMC210H1/SMC212H1 or a course in mediaeval history.

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of visual arts and architecture as mediums for expressing Christian faith. The course will examine notable developments in Christian history, the proliferation of new forms in the contemporary period, and important local works, such as the Donovan Collection and/or the rich legacy of church architecture in the GTA.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity, Art, and Architecture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 25, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to works of literary and dramatic arts from throughout the global Christian tradition. The course explores the complex relationships that exist between religious, narrative, and performative imperatives; between theological and cultural sources; between authority and experience; and between writers, playwrights, and their readerships and audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity, Literature, and Theatre

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 28, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploration of the variety of forms which Christian personal experience has taken in the course of history (martyrdom, mysticism, monasticism, sanctification of ordinary life, etc.) in order to appreciate their variety, complexity, and deep unity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Varieties of Christian Experience

cmCourseInfo.description: Episodes and issues in the development of biology, genetics and evolutionary theory in relation to Christian understandings of the natural world, the human person, and God. Possible topics include genetic determinism, mind and intelligence, gender, reproductive technologies, cosmology and ecology.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Bible and Biology

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 8, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the ways in which Scottish immigrants shaped the culture of Cape Breton and by extension Canada, with particular reference to language, literature, music and folklore.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Scots in Cape Breton
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the relationship between nationalism and unionism in post-Famine Ireland, with particular emphasis on the debates over Home Rule, the Irish Revolution and Civil War of 1916-23, the effects of partition, and the Troubles in Northern Ireland.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ireland Since the Famine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of five undergraduate full course equivalents

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced introduction to the Christian intellectual tradition through a study of key figures from several different historical periods and cultural contexts. Selected authors discuss a range of religious, intellectual and social issues, from foundational Christian beliefs to the challenges of modern, post-modern and secular cultures.
cmCourseInfo.title: Major Christian Thinkers

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: St. Michael's College Independent Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Principal of St. Michael's College. Normally restricted to students who have completed at least ten full courses with a CGPA of at least 2.5. Application forms are available in the St. Michael's College Principal's Office. A completed application signed by the student and by the supervising instructor must be submitted to the St. Michael's College Principal's Office for approval; at least one month before the beginning of the semester.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 6, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of connections between a child's moral development and literature in Christian traditions. We examine literary, historical and philosophical developments appropriate to the child's imagination. The course will include the study of poems, catechetical materials, novels and other texts written for children.
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and the Christian Child

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research methods in the Humanities focusing on quantification, the use of routinely generated records, forensic analysis, and data collection and analysis. Critique of these methods. The course focuses on multiculturalism and ethnicity in Toronto. Students will reconstruct the life of immigrant, religious, and occupational groups in the city by use of municipal assessment records, the censuses of 1901 and 1911, church records, newspapers, maps, city directories, and online databases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multicultural Toronto by the Numbers
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must be registered in major or specialist programs in SMC/SLA/FRE/GER/ITA.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Added: November 20, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to research methods in the Humanities focusing on quantification, the use of routinely generated records, forensic analysis, and data collection and analysis. Critique of these methods. The course focuses on multiculturalism and ethnicity in Toronto. Students will reconstruct the life of immigrant, religious, and occupational groups in the city by use of municipal assessment records, the censuses of 1901 and 1911, church records, newspapers, maps, city directories, and online databases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multicultural Toronto by the Numbers
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must be registered in major or specialist programs in SMC/SLA/FRE/GER/ITA.

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit is offered to a student doing an internship with a media organization formally recognized as a partner of St. Michael's College and the Book and Media Studies Program.  A faculty supervisor assesses and assigns the necessary written component cognate to the internship.
cmCourseInfo.title: Book and Media Internship
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Program Coordinator and Principal

notes.content: Room Change: September 5, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to advertising and its use in global media.  Emphasis is placed on the creative and manipulative character of contemporary advertising, the specialized messaging employed in public life and politics, and the growth of modern agencies for marketing and product promotion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advertising and Media

courses.name: Independent Study in Book and Media Studies (formerly SMC399Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: An independent research project to be proposed by the student and supervised by a full-time faculty member affiliated with the Book and Media Studies Program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses, please contact Monica Phonsavatdy at m.phonsavatdy@utoronto.ca or 416-926-7256 (50 St. Joseph Street, Odette Hall, Room 020, St. Michael's College). Topics in medieval Church history: The seminar provides an opportunity to deepen familiarity with the history of ecclesiastical institutions in the high Middle Ages (papacy, episcopate, parish structures, clerical education etc.). The seminar topics will in part be defined in accordance with the research interests of the students.

courses.name: The Irish and Scots in Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the history of Irish and Scottish migration and settlement in Canada with a special emphasis on political, social, economic and religious themes.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Irish and Scots in Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth examination of the Fenian underground in Canada during the 1860s, using primary sources to examine such issues as ethno-religious conflict, the relationship between Catholicism and Irish nationalism, and the efforts of the secret police force to infiltrate and undermine the Fenian Brotherhood.  Special attention is paid to the ways in which the state responded to the threat posed by Irish revolutionaries who supported an Irish-American invasion of Canada as a means to hit back at the British Empire and pave the way for Irish independence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Irish Nationalism in Canada

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 17, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: A course/seminar on a topic to be determined annually.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Book and Media Studies I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
From playgrounds, arenas, and tabletops to computers, mobile devices, and video game consoles, games and play are a vibrant and diverse cultural form and a fundamental part of human society. Why do we make and play games? How do games produce experiences, make meaning, and reflect or refract ideology, and what impact do they have on players? Who gets to make, play, and find representation in games and who is left out? What role do games play in the contemporary media ecosystem? This seminar-style class will explore issues around games both analog and digital from a variety of critical perspectives, including history, industry, technology, culture, politics, and aesthetics.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar explores the intellectual milieu of the cathedral schools of the twelfth century and the debates of its famous and infamous protagonists: Abelard, for instance, and Bernard of Clairvaux, Heloise, Peter the Venerable, etc. Readings in the original Latin will be discussed and commented upon by students.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Mediaeval Latin Seminar

cmCourseInfo.description: Middle Welsh, the native Celtic language of medieval Wales, was for centuries the language in which the Welsh celebrated their medieval princes and ancestral heroes, was the medium for the preservation of native British legend and Welsh law, and was the vehicle for the earliest narratives of Arthur. Students will be introduced to reading and translating Middle Welsh, and by the course’s end will have read one complete text of Middle Welsh literature in the original. Students will learn Welsh specifically but will also learn the characteristic linguistic features of a Celtic language. No prior knowledge of Welsh or any other Celtic language is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Welsh

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced study of the historical development, major theological writings and contemporary ethnographic studies of diverse Christian traditions in South Asia. Topics to be covered include the legacy of Thomas Christianity, Hindu-Christian dialogue, the Christian ashram movement, liturgical inculturation and religious hybridity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Indian Christianity

cmCourseInfo.description: A senior seminar which examines various theories of education to create critical discourse on the role of media in the classroom.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media in Education

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 26, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description:
This research seminar focuses on the history and development of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Topics for discussion include broadcast regulation, programming, relationships with the state, the ongoing struggle with private broadcasters, commercialization, Americanization, and financial questions. Students will be required to make oral presentations and prepare a research essay.

Please note that in Winter 2019 SMC466H1 will focus more broadly on Canadian cultural industries, including but not limited to public broadcasting. Final assignment structure will be announced on the syllabus and in the first week of class.
cmCourseInfo.title: Public Broadcasting in Canada
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment priority for students enrolled Book and Media Studies Major POSt

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assesses way in which governments, political parties, news agencies and other groups and institutions use media to shape particular messages or describe current events. Each week the seminar will focus on a major historical event, the manner in which it was reported and interpreted, and principal challenges to that interpretation. A wide variety of media will be analyzed including: books, newspapers, film, radio, television, and the internet. Events such as the War on Terror, the Great War, the Dreyfus Affair, the Irish Famine, and the “Red Scare” are among some of the topics that will be discussed. Students will prepare unique assignments akin to the work done by communications officers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Manipulation and History

courses.name: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: The seminar provides majors in their final year of study with the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects in Christianity and Culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Even before her death at age 19, Joan of Arc was the subject of painting, poetry and song, and she has remained a focus for the creative imagination for six hundred years. This seminar will survey artistic representations of Joan of Arc across centuries, languages, and artistic media, with a special focus on depictions of Joan in world literature. Possible authors include Christine de Pizan, Shakespeare, Schiller, Voltaire, Coleridge, Southey, Twain, Thérèse of Lisieux, Brecht, Shaw, and Péguy, in addition to classic films, graphic novels, and video games.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 8, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: The seminar provides majors in their final year of study with the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects in Christianity and Culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
How do texts make their way from premodern authors to today’s readers? This seminar is an introduction to the methods that allow us to understand this process: palaeography, textual criticism, and codicology. You will learn to read and identify the most important forms of handwriting and abbreviations used in Latin manuscripts between the fourth and fifteenth centuries. You will also understand how the process of copying by hand changed texts as we read them today, and the fundamentals of how modern scholars create a critical edition. These skills are essential for anyone wishing to conduct original research on classical and medieval primary sources. We will consider both traditional approaches to these subjects as well as evolving digital techniques. Evaluation is based on weekly transcriptions of passages from Latin manuscripts from the fourth to fifteenth centuries; an introduction to and an edition of a short text; and an examination.

cmCourseInfo.description: An opportunity for students to pursue an independent course of study not otherwise available in the Faculty of Arts and Science. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
